column2: Change our national value to Order
Change our national value to Liberty
Change our national value to Equality
Change our national value to Meritocracy

Authoritarianism is a form of government characterized by strong central power and limited political freedoms. Juan Linz's influential 1964 description of authoritarianism characterized authoritarian political systems by four qualities: limited political pluralism that is, such regimes place constraints on political institutions and groups like legislatures, political parties and interest groups a basis for legitimacy based on emotion, especially the identification of the regime as a necessary evil to combat "easily recognizable societal problems" such as underdevelopment or insurgency
column3: minimal social mobilization most often caused by constraints on the public such as suppression of political opponents and anti-regime activity informally defined executive power with often vague and shifting powers

column2: We shall change our education system to instill a value of order in our people. Our curriculum will include traditional religious philosophies, the history of our country's accomplishments, equality of all under the law, and, of course, we will teach our people that governments long established should not be changed for light and transient causes.

Liberalism is a political philosophy or worldview founded on ideas of liberty and equality. Whereas classical liberalism emphasises the role of liberty, social liberalism stresses the importance of equality. Liberals espouse a wide array of views depending on their understanding of these principles, but generally they support ideas and programmes such as freedom of speech, freedom of the press, freedom of religion, free markets, civil rights, democratic societies, secular governments, gender equality, and international cooperation.

We shall change our education system to instill a value of liberty in our people. Our curriculum will include classical philosophies and those of Milton and Locke, the history of our country's progress, equality of opportunity for all, and, of course, we will teach our people that democracy is best attained when all persons alike share in the government to the utmost.

Egalitarianism is a trend of thought that favors equality for all people. Egalitarian doctrines maintain that all humans are equal in fundamental worth or social status, according to the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. According to the Merriam-Webster Dictionary, the term has two distinct definitions in modern English: either as a political doctrine that all people should be treated as equals and have the same political, economic, social, and civil rights or as a social philosophy advocating the removal of economic inequalities among people, economic egalitarianism, or the decentralization of power. Some sources define egalitarianism as the point of view that equality reflects the natural state of humanity.

We shall change our education system to instill a value of equality in our people. Our curriculum will include the philosophies of Marx and Engels, the history of class struggle, equality of outcome to all people, and, of course, we will teach our people that the proletarians have nothing to lose but their chains.

Meritocracy is a political philosophy holding that power should be vested in individuals almost exclusively based on ability and talent. Advancement in such a system is based on performance measured through examination and/or demonstrated achievement in the field where it is implemented.

We shall change our education system to instill a value of meritocracy in our people. Our curriculum will include Enlightenment philosophy, the history of our country's innovation, political equality to those with ability, and, of course, we will teach our people that avoiding extremes gives vision, gives knowledge, and leads to calm, to insight, and to englightenment.
